member.name: T:StringConverter
member.summary: Universal conversion and parsing methods for strings. These methods are avaiblable throught the generic object.ConvertTo method: Feel free to provide additional converns for string or any other object type.

example.code: var value = "123"; var numeric = value.ConvertTo().ToInt32();

member.name: M:StringConverter.ToInt32(IConverter{System.String})
member.summary: Converts a string to an Int32 value

example.code: var value = "123"; var numeric = value.ConvertTo().ToInt32();

member.name: M:StringConverter.ToInt32(IConverter{System.String},System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a string to an Int32 value
member.param: if set to true any parsing exception will be ignored.

example.code: var value = "123"; var numeric = value.ConvertTo().ToInt32();

member.summary: Converts a regular string into SecureString

member.returns: Returns a SecureString containing the value of a transformed object.

member.summary: Coverts the SecureString to a regular string.

T:DirectoryInfoExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for the DirectoryInfo class

member.name: M:DirectoryInfoExtensions.GetFiles(System.IO.DirectoryInfo,System.String[])
member.summary: Gets all files in the directory matching one of the several (!) supplied patterns (instead of just one in the regular implementation).
member.remarks: This methods is quite perfect to be used in conjunction with the newly created FileInfo-Array extension methods.

example.code: var files = directory.GetFiles("*.txt", "*.xml");

member.name: M:DirectoryInfoExtensions.FindFileRecursive(System.IO.DirectoryInfo,System.String)
member.summary: Searches the provided directory recursively and returns the first file matching the provided pattern.

example.code: var directory = new DirectoryInfo(@"c:\"); var file = directory.FindFileRecursive("win.ini");

member.name: M:DirectoryInfoExtensions.FindFileRecursive(System.IO.DirectoryInfo,System.Func{System.IO.FileInfo,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Searches the provided directory recursively and returns the first file matching to the provided predicate.

example.code: var directory = new DirectoryInfo(@"c:\"); var file = directory.FindFileRecursive(f => f.Extension == ".ini");

member.name: M:DirectoryInfoExtensions.FindFilesRecursive(System.IO.DirectoryInfo,System.String)
member.summary: Searches the provided directory recursively and returns the all files matching the provided pattern.
member.remarks: This methods is quite perfect to be used in conjunction with the newly created FileInfo-Array extension methods.

example.code: var directory = new DirectoryInfo(@"c:\"); var files = directory.FindFilesRecursive("*.ini");

member.name: M:DirectoryInfoExtensions.FindFilesRecursive(System.IO.DirectoryInfo,System.Func{System.IO.FileInfo,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Searches the provided directory recursively and returns the all files matching to the provided predicate.
member.remarks: This methods is quite perfect to be used in conjunction with the newly created FileInfo-Array extension methods.

example.code: var directory = new DirectoryInfo(@"c:\"); var files = directory.FindFilesRecursive(f => f.Extension == ".ini");

member.name: M:PGK.Extensions.ObjectExtensions.IsNull(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns TRUE, if specified target reference is equals with null reference. Othervise returns FALSE.
member.remarks:
Some types has overloaded '==' and '!=' operators. So the code "null == ((MyClass)null)" can returns false. The most correct way how to test for null reference is using "System.Object.ReferenceEquals(object, object)" method. However the notation with ReferenceEquals method is long and uncomfortable - this extension method solve it.
Contributed by tencokacistromy, http://www.codeplex.com/site/users/view/tencokacistromy

members.member:
The ToFriendlyString() method represents dates in a user friendly way. For example, when displaying a news article on a webpage, you might want articles that were published one day ago to have their publish dates represented as "yesterday at 12:30 PM". Or if the article was publish today, show the date as "Today, 3:33 PM".
The date. Specific Culture string
modified by jtolar to implement culture settings ///

The ToFriendlyString() method represents dates in a user friendly way. For example, when displaying a news article on a webpage, you might want articles that were published one day ago to have their publish dates represented as "yesterday at 12:30 PM". Or if the article was publish today, show the date as "Today, 3:33 PM". Uses DefaultCulture from ExtensionMethodSetting.
The date. string
modified by jtolar to implement culture settings ///
